summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2020 between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) prosecutors, contractors, and FBI personnel regarding significant delays and technical challenges in processing digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The emails discuss problems with data extraction, formatting, and the urgent need for evidence review in connection with the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The digital evidence being processed was seized from his residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands. He is the central subject of the underlying investigation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The emails state the evidence is needed for the case against her, specifically seeking old emails from servers rather than newer devices.

connections.description: The document references evidence seized from Epstein's properties being critical for the case against Maxwell, indicating their alleged association in criminal activity.

events.title: Email discussion on evidence processing delays
events.description: SDNY prosecutors and FBI personnel correspond about significant delays in processing digital evidence from Epstein searches, with the FBI over a month past their estimate. They discuss technical problems with iPhone extractions and the need for a vendor to expedite the work.

events.title: FBI provides update on evidence processing
events.description: An FBI CART Coordinator provides an update, stating they are exporting materials from both NY and USVI searches, with the biggest stumbling block being newer Mac items from the Island in APFS format.

events.title: Proposal to hire external vendor BRG
events.description: A proposal is made to hire an external vendor, BRG, to process all the seized digital evidence for $85-135K, with an estimated completion time of under a month, due to FBI delays.

locations: U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI) - Epstein's island property
keyFacts: The FBI was experiencing significant delays (over a month past estimates) in processing the voluminous digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands.
The evidence from the US Virgin Islands was described as 'vastly more voluminous' than the New York materials and constituted the 'overwhelming majority of the data.'

Prosecutors urgently needed the evidence, particularly old emails from servers, for the case against Ghislaine Maxwell, noting that newer devices were purchased years after she was 'out of the picture.'

Technical challenges included problematic iPhone extractions, difficulties with newer Mac items using the APFS file system, and prior data transfers that were not in a usable, searchable format for the prosecution.
A proposal was made to hire an external vendor, BRG, for $85-135K to process all the data into a Relativity-friendly format within a month, due to the FBI's delays.
